steps.description:
Steps is the list of commands to run to build the artifact(s).
Each step is run sequentially and will be cached accordingly depending on the frontend implementation.

env.description: Env is the list of environment variables to set for all commands in this step group.

ArtifactBuild.description: ArtifactBuild configures a group of steps that are run sequentially along with their outputs to build the artifact(s).

subpath.description:
Subpath is the subpath to use in the package for the artifact type.

As an example, binaries are typically placed in /usr/bin when installed.
If you want to nest them in a subdirectory, you can specify it here.

name.description:
Name is file or dir name to use for the artifact in the package.
If empty, the file or dir name from the produced artifact will be used.

ArtifactConfig.description: ArtifactConfig is the configuration for a given artifact type.

mode.description:
Mode is used to set the file permission bits of the final created directory to the specified mode.
Mode is the octal permissions to set on the dir.

ArtifactDirConfig.description: ArtifactDirConfig contains information about the directory to be created

binaries.description: Binaries is the list of binaries to include in the package.

manpages.description: Manpages is the list of manpages to include in the package.

createDirectories.description: Directories is a list of various directories that should be created by the package.

configFiles.description: ConfigFiles is a list of files that should be marked as config files in the package.

docs.description: Docs is a list of doc files included in the package

licenses.description: Licenses is a list of doc files included in the package

systemd.description: SystemdConfigurations is the list of systemd units and dropin files for the package

Artifacts.description: Artifacts describes all the artifacts to include in the package.

command.description:
Command is the command to run to build the artifact(s).
This will always be wrapped as /bin/sh -c "<command>", or whatever the equivalent is for the target distro.

env.description: Env is the list of environment variables to set for the command.

BuildStep.description: BuildStep is used to execute a command to build the artifact(s).

mode.description:
Mode is the locking mode to set on the cache directory
values: shared, private, locked
default: shared

key.description:
Key is the cache key to use to cache the directory
default: Value of `Path`

include_distro_key.description:
IncludeDistroKey is used to include the distro key as part of the cache key
What this key is depends on the frontend implementation
Example for Debian Buster may be "buster"

An example use for this is with a Go(lang) build cache when CGO is included.
Go is unable to invalidate cgo and re-using the same cache across different distros may cause issues.

include_arch_key.description:
IncludeArchKey is used to include the architecture key as part of the cache key
What this key is depends on the frontend implementation
Frontends SHOULD use the buildkit platform arch

As with [IncludeDistroKey], this is useful for Go(lang) builds with CGO.

CacheDirConfig.description: CacheDirConfig configures a persistent cache to be used across builds.

date.description: Date is the date of the changelog entry.

author.description: Author is the author of the changelog entry. e.g. `John Smith <john.smith@example.com>`

changes.description: Changes is the list of changes in the changelog entry.

ChangelogEntry.description: ChangelogEntry is an entry in the changelog.

equals.description: Equals is the exact string to compare the output to.

contains.description: Contains is the list of strings to check if they are contained in the output.

matches.description: Matches is the regular expression to match the output against.

starts_with.description: StartsWith is the string to check if the output starts with.

ends_with.description: EndsWith is the string to check if the output ends with.

empty.description: Empty is used to check if the output is empty.

CheckOutput.description: CheckOutput is used to specify the exepcted output of a check, such as stdout/stderr or a file.

dir.description: Dir is the working directory to run the command in.

mounts.description: Mounts is the list of sources to mount into the build steps.

cache_dirs.description: List of CacheDirs which will be used across all Steps

env.description: Env is the list of environment variables to set for all commands in this step group.

steps.description:
Steps is the list of commands to run to generate the source.
Steps are run sequentially and results of each step should be cached.

Command.description: Command is used to execute a command to generate a source from a docker image.

Config.description: Config is a list of directories the RPM should place under the system config directory (i.e. /etc)

State.description: State is a list of directories the RPM should place under the common directory for shared state and libs (i.e. /var/lib).

CreateArtifactDirectories.description: CreateArtifactDirectories describes various directories that should be created on install.

equals.description: Equals is the exact string to compare the output to.

contains.description: Contains is the list of strings to check if they are contained in the output.

matches.description: Matches is the regular expression to match the output against.

starts_with.description: StartsWith is the string to check if the output starts with.

ends_with.description: EndsWith is the string to check if the output ends with.

empty.description: Empty is used to check if the output is empty.

permissions.description: Permissions is the expected permissions of the file.

is_dir.description: IsDir is used to set the expected file mode to a directory.

not_exist.description: NotExist is used to check that the file does not exist.

FileCheckOutput.description: FileCheckOutput is used to specify the expected output of a file.

image.description:
Image specifies the frontend image to forward the build to.
This can be left unspecified *if* the original frontend has builtin support for the distro.

If the original frontend does not have builtin support for the distro, this must be specified or the build will fail.
If this is specified then it MUST be used.

cmdline.description:
CmdLine is the command line to use to forward the build to the frontend.
By default the frontend image's entrypoint/cmd is used.

Frontend.description: Frontend encapsulates the configuration for a frontend to forward a build target to.

GeneratorGomod.description: GeneratorGomod is used to generate a go module cache from go module sources

entrypoint.description:
Entrypoint sets the image's "entrypoint" field.
This is used to control the default command to run when the image is run.

cmd.description:
Cmd sets the image's "cmd" field.
When entrypoint is set, this is used as the default arguments to the entrypoint.
When entrypoint is not set, this is used as the default command to run.

env.description: Env is the list of environment variables to set in the image.

labels.description: Labels is the list of labels to set in the image metadata.

volumes.description:
Volumes is the list of volumes for the image.
Volumes instruct the runtime to bypass the any copy-on-write filesystems and mount the volume directly to the container.

working_dir.description:
WorkingDir is the working directory to set in the image.
This sets the directory the container will start in.

stop_signal.description:
StopSignal is the signal to send to the container to stop it.
This is used to stop the container gracefully.

base.description:
Base is the base image to use for the output image.
This only affects the output image, not the intermediate build image.

post.description:
Post is the post install configuration for the image.
This allows making additional modifications to the container rootfs after the package(s) are installed.

Use this to perform actions that would otherwise require additional tooling inside the container that is not relavent to
the resulting container and makes a post-install script as part of the package unnecessary.

user.description: User is the that the image should run as.

ImageConfig.description: ImageConfig is the configuration for the output image.

signer.description: Signer is the configuration to use for signing packages

PackageConfig.description: PackageConfig encapsulates the configuration for artifact targets

build.description: Build is the list of packagese required to build the package.

runtime.description: Runtime is the list of packages required to install/run the package.

recommends.description:
Recommends is the list of packages recommended to install with the generated package.
Note: Not all package managers support this (e.g. rpm)

test.description:
Test lists any extra packages required for running tests
These packages are only installed for tests which have steps that require
running a command in the built container.
See [TestSpec] for more information.

PackageDependencies.description: PackageDependencies is a list of dependencies for a package.

source.description: Source is the name of the source that contains the patch to apply.

strip.description:
Strip is the number of leading path components to strip from the patch.
The default is 1 which is typical of a git diff.

PatchSpec.description: PatchSpec is used to apply a patch to a source with a given set of options.

symlinks.description:
Symlinks is the list of symlinks to create in the container rootfs after the package(s) are installed.
The key is the path the symlink should point to.

PostInstall.description: PostInstall is the post install configuration for the image.

image.description:
This is an embedded union representing all of the possible source types.
Exactly one must be non-nil, with all other cases being errors.

=== Begin Source Variants ===

path.description: Path is the path to the source after fetching it based on the identifier.

includes.description:
Includes is a list of paths underneath `Path` to include, everything else is execluded
If empty, everything is included (minus the excludes)

excludes.description: Excludes is a list of paths underneath `Path` to exclude, everything else is included

generate.description:
Generate is the list generators to run on the source.

Generators are used to generate additional sources from this source.
As an example the `godmod` generator can be used to generate a go module cache from a go source.
How a genator operates is dependent on the actual generator.
Geneators may also cauuse modifications to the build environment.

Currently only one generator is supported: "gomod"

Source.description: Source defines a source to be used in the build.

source.description: A source specification to use as the context for the Dockerfile build

dockerfile_path.description:
DockerfilePath is the path to the build file in the build context
If not set the default is assumed by buildkit to be `Dockerfile` at the root of the context.

target.description:
Target specifies the build target to use.
If unset, the default target is determined by the frontend implementation
(e.g. the dockerfile frontend uses the last build stage as the default).

args.description: Args are the build args to pass to the build.

SourceBuild.description: SourceBuild is used to generate source from a DockerFile build.

name.description:
Name is the name of the build context. By default, it is the magic name
`context`, recognized by Docker as the default context.

SourceContext.description: SourceContext is used to generate a source from a build context.

subpath.description: Subpath is the path inside a source to run the generator from.

gomod.description: Gomod is the go module generator.

SourceGenerator.description: SourceGenerator holds the configuration for a source generator.

url.description: URL is the URL to download the file from.

digest.description:
Digest is the digest of the file to download.
This is used to verify the integrity of the file.
Form: <algorithm>:<digest>

SourceHTTP.description: SourceHTTP is used to download a file from an HTTP(s) URL.

file.description:
File is the inline file to generate.
File is treated as a literal single file.
[SourceIsDir] will return false when this is set.
This is mutally exclusive with [Dir]

dir.description:
Dir creates a directory with the given files and directories.
[SourceIsDir] will return true when this is set.
This is mutally exclusive with [File]

SourceInline.description: SourceInline is used to generate a source from inline content.

files.description:
Files is the list of files to include in the directory.
The map key is the name of the file.

Files with path separators in the key will be rejected.

permissions.description: Permissions is the octal permissions to set on the directory.

uid.description:
UID is the user ID to set on the directory and all files and directories within it.
UID must be greater than or equal to 0

gid.description:
GID is the group ID to set on the directory and all files and directories within it.
UID must be greater than or equal to 0

SourceInlineDir.description: SourceInlineDir is used by by [SourceInline] to represent a filesystem directory.

permissions.description: Permissions is the octal file permissions to set on the file.

uid.description:
UID is the user ID to set on the directory and all files and directories within it.
UID must be greater than or equal to 0

gid.description:
GID is the group ID to set on the directory and all files and directories within it.
UID must be greater than or equal to 0

SourceInlineFile.description: SourceInlineFile is used to specify the content of an inline source.

dest.description: Dest is the destination directory to mount to

spec.description: Spec specifies the source to mount

SourceMount.description: SourceMount is used to take a [Source] and mount it into a build step.

name.description: Name is the name of the package.

description.description: Description is a short description of the package.

website.description: Website is the URL to store in the metadata of the package.

version.description: Version sets the version of the package.

revision.description:
Revision sets the package revision.
This will generally get merged into the package version when generating the package.

noarch.description:
Marks the package as architecture independent.
It is up to the package author to ensure that the package is actually architecture independent.
This is metadata only.

conflicts.description:
Conflicts is the list of packages that conflict with the generated package.
This will prevent the package from being installed if any of these packages are already installed or vice versa.

replaces.description: Replaces is the list of packages that are replaced by the generated package.

provides.description:
Provides is the list of things that the generated package provides.
This can be used to satisfy dependencies of other packages.
As an example, the moby-runc package provides "runc", other packages could depend on "runc" and be satisfied by moby-runc.
This is an advanced use case and consideration should be taken to ensure that the package actually provides the thing it claims to provide.

sources.description:
Sources is the list of sources to use to build the artifact(s).
The map key is the name of the source and the value is the source configuration.
The source configuration is used to fetch the source and filter the files to include/exclude.
This can be mounted into the build using the "Mounts" field in the StepGroup.

Sources can be embedded in the main spec as here or overriden in a build request.

patches.description:
Patches is the list of patches to apply to the sources.
The map key is the name of the source to apply the patches to.
The value is the list of patches to apply to the source.
The patch must be present in the `Sources` map.
Each patch is applied in order and the result is used as the source for the build.

build.description: Build is the configuration for building the artifacts in the package.

args.description:
Args is the list of arguments that can be used for shell-style expansion in (certain fields of) the spec.
Any arg supplied in the build request which does not appear in this list will cause an error.
Attempts to use an arg in the spec which is not specified here will assume to be a literal string.
The map value is the default value to use if the arg is not supplied in the build request.

license.description: License is the license of the package.

vendor.description: Vendor is the vendor of the package.

packager.description: Packager is the name of the person,team,company that packaged the package.

artifacts.description: Artifacts is the list of artifacts to include in the package.

targets.description: The list of distro targets to build the package for.

dependencies.description:
Dependencies are the different dependencies that need to be specified in the package.
Dependencies are overwritten if specified in the target map for the requested distro.

package_config.description:
PackageConfig is the configuration to use for artifact targets, such as
rpms, debs, or zip files containing Windows binaries

image.description:
Image is the image configuration when the target output is a container image.
This is overwritten if specified in the target map for the requested distro.

changelog.description: Changelog is the list of changes to the package.

tests.description:
Tests are the list of tests to run for the package that should work regardless of target OS
Each item in this list is run with a separate rootfs and cannot interact with other tests.
Each [TestSpec] is run with a separate rootfs, asyncronously from other [TestSpec].

Spec.description: Spec is the specification for a package build.

path.description: Path is the path where the symlink should be placed

SymlinkTarget.description: SymlinkTarget specifies the properties of a symlink

units.description: SystemdUnits is a list of systemd units to include in the package.

SystemdDropins.description: SystemdDropins is a list of systemd drop in files that should be included in the package

name.description:
Name is file or dir name to use for the artifact in the package.
If empty, the file or dir name from the produced artifact will be used.

unit.description: Unit is the name of the systemd unit that the dropin files should be copied under.

name.description:
Name is the name systemd unit should be copied under.
Nested paths are not supported. It is the user's responsibility
to name the service with the appropriate extension, i.e. .service, .timer, etc.

enable.description:
Enable is used to enable the systemd unit on install
This determines what will be written to a systemd preset file

dependencies.description: Dependencies are the different dependencies that need to be specified in the package.

image.description: Image is the image configuration when the target output is a container image.

frontend.description:
Frontend is the frontend configuration to use for the target.
This is used to forward the build to a different, dalec-compatabile frontend.
This can be useful when testing out new distros or using a different version of the frontend for a given distro.

tests.description:
Tests are the list of tests to run which are specific to the target.
Tests are appended to the list of tests in the main [Spec]

package_config.description:
PackageConfig is the configuration to use for artifact targets, such as
rpms, debs, or zip files containing Windows binaries

Target.description: Target defines a distro-specific build target.

name.description:
Name is the name of the test
This will be used to output the test results

dir.description: Dir is the working directory to run the command in.

mounts.description: Mounts is the list of sources to mount into the build steps.

cache_dirs.description: List of CacheDirs which will be used across all Steps

env.description: Env is the list of environment variables to set for all commands in this step group.

steps.description: Steps is the list of commands to run to test the package.

files.description: Files is the list of files to check after running the steps.

TestSpec.description: TestSpec is used to execute tests against a container with the package installed in it.

command.description:
Command is the command to run to build the artifact(s).
This will always be wrapped as /bin/sh -c "<command>", or whatever the equivalent is for the target distro.

env.description: Env is the list of environment variables to set for the command.

stdout.description: Stdout is the expected output on stdout

stderr.description: Stderr is the expected output on stderr

stdin.description: Stdin is the input to pass to stdin for the command

TestStep.description: TestStep is a wrapper for [BuildStep] to include checks on stdio streams
